user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_nodelay_state_:
```c
bool
MHD_connection_set_nodelay_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                   bool nodelay_state)
{
#ifdef TCP_NODELAY
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
  int err_code;

  if (_MHD_YES == connection->is_nonip)
    return false;

  if (0 == setsockopt (connection->socket_fd,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       TCP_NODELAY,
                       (const void *) (nodelay_state ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (off_val)))
  {
    connection->sk_nodelay = nodelay_state;
    return true;
  }

  err_code = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();
  if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOPROTOOPT_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOTSOCK_))
  {
    if (_MHD_UNKNOWN == connection->is_nonip)
      connection->is_nonip = _MHD_YES;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    else
    {
      MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed "
                   "for TCP/IP socket %d: %s\n"),
                "TCP_NODELAY",
                nodelay_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
                (int) connection->socket_fd,
                MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
    }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
  }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  else
  {
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed: %s\n"),
              "TCP_NODELAY",
              nodelay_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
              MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */

#else  /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
  (void) connection; (void) nodelay_state; /* Mute compiler warnings */
#endif /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions were detected in the provided code. I checked for common compiler-specific extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions, including but not limited to: __attribute__ annotations, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), inline assembler (asm / __asm__), __extension__, __builtin_* intrinsics, unnamed or zero-length bit-fields used as extensions, variadic macros with nonstandard behavior, and other vendor-specific keywords. The code uses standard C constructs: conditional compilation (#ifdef TCP_NODELAY / HAVE_MESSAGES), standard casts, the ternary operator, pointer operations, (void) casts to silence warnings, and the identifier bool which is the standard C99/_Bool (via stdbool.h) rather than a compiler extension. Use of POSIX socket options (setsockopt, TCP_NODELAY, IPPROTO_TCP) are OS/API features, not compiler language extensions. Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
